text: Thank you so much, Dani, for kind words! When I read your message I feel myself much better!:slightly_smiling_face:

I’m in counselling too as I think it's completely unfair to exploit my friend for this purpose. Of course, now and then I do it lol (just kidding, I don’t). We discuss different topics as it’s very interesting to look on things (issues, etc) from a different perspective.

I'll even say more – I was in a fight with depression over 10 years (approx.). I used to never speak about this as I thought that this would make me vulnerable and people won’t understand because of misconception about depression.
But I won. Unbelievable - even for myself. I was fighting it alone, which was a huge mistake.

Maybe this is the reason I want to help people and be with them if they need me. I’ve hit bottom – and I ‘ve got back. I didn’t have anyone when I needed. Just someone to talk to. But I can change it now. And I can be that person who will be there when you need me.
That’s the story, haha :sweat_smile: Bit boring, bit sad, I know, and I totally agree with it. But I believe it’s important to speak about that as it can change or even save someone's life.
*_Now let’s get back to a good bit! Yay!_*

Definitely! I’m so happy to figure out with you what is mentoring! It is a big honour for me to have you as a mentor, to know you, work with you and become industry friends. Personally, it's still cosmic and a bit unbelievable to have this opportunity. But I’m very thankful for this chance, and I try to do all I can to use it.
_Thank you so much for your support. That means a lot to me! _
_Thank you so much for your support. That means a lot to me! _

This situation with uni is quite revealing. There will always be some obstacles, inconsistencies. It's life. However, I’ve tried to use these 1,5 months with great benefit for myself. I was not only learning Maya, but I was also learning good working habits and was looking at different pipelines/work approaches. How to make an animation from blocking down to final refined piece; or how to speed up the process without loosing in quality.
There are still many things for me to learn (they are on my list), but that was an excellent start to build a strong foundation.

Sadly, most of it is not taught at university. Some bits and bobs are – but without someone experienced with a good explanation it’s hardly possible to make a system out of it in your head as a student.

My main concern is time. I could spend it making an actual animation. But instead, I had to learn on the side to get the required knowledge for my work. And I’m now left with 2 weeks for projects that usually takes 2 months at least (if I want to get a good and refined result). But I’ll come to this later.
I want to apologise, for not adding some additional info about 3d max. I’ll try to fix it :male-construction-worker:

I love 3ds max. It’s a wonderful piece of software. I was working in it pretty much non stop for 2 years – on my foundation and my first years.

I was concerned that the university is not implementing Maya – even on a simple level (for example, learning the interface). Therefore pretty much every student is afraid of Maya.

I want to make my self very clear – we have amazing lecturers! They do what they love, and they do it well. However, the main problems lie in the course structure. It’s lovely to know that they are creating the new one. And despite all the changes, the clock keeps ticking for us as these changes won’t have any impact on our course. So, we have to find ways around it — this why I’m trying to self-educate myself.

I apologise for bringing this up again - this will be the last time. I think that this’s important for explaining certain things.
Moreover, I feel myself bad by doing that (bringing this up one more time), becouse I feel like I’m wasting time that could be used for mentoring.

Although maybe I‘m entirely wrong and discussing these things are a part of mentoring and are essential. I’m not sure.
*_Nevertheless, to the next topic, haha!_*

_• About foundation year._

I’ve decided to take it, simply because in our country we don’t do colleges. The education system in Estonia is built in a slightly different way than in England. We finish with 12 grades. I have no right to compare difficulty level with the UK because I did not study here (elementary, middle or high schools). But from my experience education is very intensive. We end up with 16 subjects in general (in our diploma). Some subjects we finish in 9th grade and they transfer from the end of middle school down to the high school (we call it gymnasium) diploma. At least that was the case back in 2012. A severe reform of education followed this. So, I’m not entirely sure how things are going now.

Anyway, after graduation, we are eligible to apply for higher education (without a need to go to college).

Again, I don’t have a right to discuss that, as I have never been in college. But I think it is a necessary and useful step (bridge) between secondary and higher education; as it prepares you for your future career.

As an example – I should feel that gap by taking a foundation year at university, instead of going to college.
So, the college is a good step on the way to higher education (it’s only my subjective opinion).
*_Before I carry on, I want to say thank you so much for such broad and detailed answers! Dani, thank you for your time and support! _*
_• About emotions, feelings and poses_

For past 1,5 months, I’ve just taught essentials. I clearly understand that. And you’re so right about feeling hungry to learn more and more and more. That, on the other hand, makes me worry about the time I have at university to do all that, but I’ll make it. At least I try to make it!
Next steps will be to learn – Body Mechanics, then Acting, the Advanced acting, then facial animation. I have materials to learn from (tutorials, videos and books). It’s a matter of time only. On top of that, I want to learn more about psychology behind animation. I mean, for example, what stands behind our perception of the strong or weak character. What are these signals that tell observer about it? Another simple example are the shapes – rounded body shapes, squared or triangled. These things already send a signal (subconsciously) to a viewer about who is the character.

_ “The devil is in the detail”. _

I have not been going back home for Christmas or the New Year for past 5 years. So, this December, after the end of the 1st semester I’ll start on Body Mechanics.

So, hopefully, after that I’ll be able to bring to the screens a believable character motion.
_I’ll definitely send you an animation block out - ~when I get it sorted lol~_

_*Thank you for spending your own time for me and my work! I truly believe that time is the most precious thing we have in life. We (people) can spend it but never get it back. That’s why this is a very special thing!*_

I know that I’m saying “Thank you” too many times. But I might not have any of that. People (I have seen myself a lot of examples) take many things in life as granted. We can walk, we can breathe, we have freedom of movement. It’s invaluable. And I believe that it’s good practice to appreciate it.

Sometimes, I close my eyes and try to find 10 things to be thankful for. After that simple ritual, I appreciate my life even more for everything I have.

The project I’ll send you will be “60-second animation” But I want to let you know, that I’ve changed my plans a bit for now and therefore I’ll send it to you later. I’ve done that for a reason. I have only 2 weeks left before the deadlines. So in order for me to stay on track (remain in the course), I have to do a lot of work in the extremely short amount of time. I’ll start of "2 walk cycles", "2 run cycles", "the vault", then "weight exercise", then "emote".

I’ve changed priorities to get the most out the time I have.

For the reasons above I have nothing to send for now.
_• Perfectionism _

Also– is really hard for me to submit these project, as I know that they will be far behind from personal standards. These animations will be done for 20% out of 100%.
I won't have time to check the poses, check on and improve arcs, spacing, refine an animation.

*_Perfectionism_* is something I’m working on for a long time. I’m aware, that I’ll be paid for speed. So, I have to achieve a balance between _speed/quality_. I’ll get there.

*_Perfectionism_* – is a double-edged sword. It’s an internal battle that I’m trying to win.

I’ll surely send you a block out when I finish with these animations and a quick green screen animation (film myself and animate a character in 3d) and then compose these animations into one.  These projects are from different modules. So, by submitting most of it, I’ll increase my chances get to the 2nd semester without any problems.

It’s hard for me to say what I’ve said (sounds probable, like I don’t take my study seriously). The previous year I’ve got 1st in the animation module. I’m not feeling comfortable to be in this position. However, I believe that this investment into knowledge and skill I’ve done for previous 1,5 will bring benefits in the long run.

I get used to working under pressure. It’s not a big deal for me. It’s more about coming to consensus with myself.
*_Thank you! Thank you! Thank you! I hope you’ve got to this point. I’m so sorry for writing so much. It’s just so many things I want to share and ask you!_*

All these thoughts are a good representation of what happens in my head on a daily basis. I’m not offended when people say that they are getting tired when I speak about things. I’m very fast-paced talker (learn to change it). As my colleagues say: “You can speak for England” That’s true, haha :sweat_smile:
_* Can I ask you please 2 questions?_
_*Questions:*_
_• Is it convenient to use a drawing tablet for animation?_

I bought myself a drawing tablet 2 years ago as this was a requirement for _Photoshop_ module on the foundation year). Afterwards, I didn’t use it because we were doing a lot of hard surface modelling and traditional/stop-motion animation.

However, recently I have discovered a video of an animator who described his experience working with a tablet - when he was a student and when he got his first job. He says when you get used to it, it’s like touching a model with your own hands. And most important – it speeds up the workflow in many times!

I have a vertical mouse, which is more physiological. Ergonomics of that computer mouse helps to avoid carpal tunnel syndrome. However, it’s still a mouse. So, I was curious about the possibility of utilising a drawing tablet and get into the habit. What do you think about that?
_• Is it worth applying for an internship as a runner?_

We’ve got 2 internships offers sent by our course leader. Both are for Disney Channel - London.
- PRODUCTION MANAGEMENT
- CREATIVE INTERNSHIP

Both of them are more about advertising, working with Photoshop and other apps. Post stuff in social media, etc.
So, not that much to do with animation.
A bad example -  my acquaintance (from Estonia), who finished Bradford University in Biomedical Science decided not to take a placement/internship and therefore didn’t find a job afterwards. She was looking for 6 months and then gave up.
Placement/internship is essential. It’s clear to me.

What I’m concerned about is:
*  it’s not much to do with animation.
* my animation skills will fade away withing the time
* it’s not paid
I’m fine with not get paid. I have to start somewhere. However, it’s London. It’s expensive.
I’m not saying that I’ll get it. I’m just trying to figure out is it worth it if any of the same position will appear in the future.
I entirely depend on myself, and I have savings. However, I’m trying to figure out the next:

This position – is it worth spending time and money on it?
